But the app still works with only six Sprint and Virgin Mobile phones, which is just one of the challenges that Google and other mobile payment services face.

docs.snippet: HOME IMPROVEMENT BATTLE The American home improvement chain Lowe's said on Tuesday that it would continue to pursue a deal for Rona, a Canadian rival, after its $1.8 billion takeover offer was rejected. But the province of Quebec, where Rona has i...
docs.lead_paragraph: HOME IMPROVEMENT BATTLE The American home improvement chain Lowe's said on Tuesday that it would continue to pursue a deal for Rona, a Canadian rival, after its $1.8 billion takeover offer was rejected. But the province of Quebec, where Rona has its headquarters, said that it would try to prevent any takeover. In a statement, Rona, which is led by Robert Dutton, above, said that it was approached by Lowe's on July 8 and that it formally rejected the offer on Thursday. IAN AUSTEN

docs.snippet: Q. I'm wondering what data my installed Android apps can see and use on my phone. Is there a way to tell?     A. When you install a new app on your Android smartphone, the program presents you with a list of permissions, and it is up to you to dec...
docs.lead_paragraph: Q. I'm wondering what data my installed Android apps can see and use on my phone. Is there a way to tell? A. When you install a new app on your Android smartphone, the program presents you with a list of permissions, and it is up to you to decide if you want to continue installing the app. (You aren't allowed to pick and choose among the functions.) These permissions can include access to your contacts list, network connection, location information and so on. If you want to look before installing, the Permissions tab on the app's Google Play Web page also lists what, if any, personal information or system data the app can use.

headline.main: Checking Permissions On Android Apps

docs.abstract: Personal Tech Q&A column on checking permissions on Android smartphone apps. (S)1

docs.snippet: John Noerr and his 5-year-old son were chasing snakes in the Adirondacks last month when they stumbled on a grimy, expensive digital camera sitting in a foot of water in a stream.Mr. Noerr, a 39-year-old art teacher, took a screwdriver and pried o...
docs.lead_paragraph: John Noerr and his 5-year-old son were chasing snakes in the Adirondacks last month when they stumbled on a grimy, expensive digital camera sitting in a foot of water in a stream.Mr. Noerr, a 39-year-old art teacher, took a screwdriver and pried open a flap that concealed the camera's memory card. He extracted the card, cleaned it off and put it in his computer.

headline.main: After 3 Years in the Adirondacks, a Lost Camera Reveals Secrets to Its Home Far Away

docs.abstract: Vermonter John Noerr, who stumbled on a digital camera sitting in a foot of water in a stream in the Adironacks while on vacation, spent hours on the Internet in an effort to match some of the photos on the camera's memory card to locations in Google maps; he succeeds in returning the card, its 581 pictures intact, to its ecstatic owner in Brooklyn, who had lost it three years earlier. (M)t

docs.snippet: 4:45 p.m. | Updated  Adding background and details, response from  Google . The rift between  Apple  and Google just got a little wider. On Monday, Apple released a test version of its coming iOS 6 operating system, which powers iPads and iPhones,...
docs.lead_paragraph: 4:45 p.m. | Updated Adding background and details, response from Google . The rift between Apple and Google just got a little wider. On Monday, Apple released a test version of its coming iOS 6 operating system, which powers iPads and iPhones, and developers promptly noticed that the YouTube app was missing from its lineup of built-in apps.

headline.main: Apple Drops YouTube App In Mobile System Update

docs.abstract: Apple releases a test version of its coming iOS 6 operating system, minus the YouTube app from its lineup of built-in apps; change is noteworthy because Apple has included the YouTube app with iOS since it released the first iPhone in 2007; disappearance seems to chill any remnants of warmth that once existed between Apple and Google, which owns YouTube. (M)

byline.original: By NICK WINGFIELD and CLAIRE CAIN MILLER

docs.snippet: SAN FRANCISCO - The Federal Trade Commission fined Google $22.5 million on Thursday to settle charges that it had bypassed privacy settings in Apple's Safari browser to be able to track users of the browser and show them advertisements, and violat...
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO - The Federal Trade Commission fined Google $22.5 million on Thursday to settle charges that it had bypassed privacy settings in Apple's Safari browser to be able to track users of the browser and show them advertisements, and violated an earlier privacy settlement with the agency.The fine is the largest civil penalty ever levied by the commission, which has been cracking down on tech companies for privacy violations and is also investigating Google for antitrust violations.

headline.main: Google, Accused of Skirting Privacy Provision, Is to Pay $22.5 Million to Settle Charges

docs.abstract: Federal Trade Commission fines Google $22.5 million to settle charges that it bypassed privacy settings in Apple's Safari browser to be able to track users of the browser and show them advertisements, and violated an earlier privacy settlement with the agency; fine is largest civil penalty ever levied by the commission. (M)

docs.snippet: 6:58 p.m. | Updated  Big media companies won a battle in the fight to combat online piracy on Friday when Google said it would alter its search algorithms to favor Web sites that offered legitimate copyrighted movies, music and television.Google s...
docs.lead_paragraph: 6:58 p.m. | Updated Big media companies won a battle in the fight to combat online piracy on Friday when Google said it would alter its search algorithms to favor Web sites that offered legitimate copyrighted movies, music and television.Google said that beginning next week its algorithms would take into account the number of valid copyright removal notices Web sites have received. Web sites with multiple, valid complaints about copyright infringement may appear lower in Google search results.

headline.main: Under Copyright Pressure, Google to Alter Search Results

docs.abstract: Google says it will alter its algorithms to take into account the number of valid copyright removal notices Web sites have received as big media companies win a battle in the fight to combat online privacy; new formula will favor Web sites that offer legitimate copyrighted movies, music and television. (M)l

headline.main: Daily Report: Google Unveils Plans for Motorola

docs.abstract: Motorola Mobility, the ailing cellphone maker that Google bought in May, told employees Sunday that it would lay off 20 percent of its work force and close a third of its 94 offices worldwide, Claire Cain Miller reports in Monday's New York Times.

docs.snippet: The cuts are the first step in Google’s plan to reinvent the company that it bought in May, and to shore up its Android mobile business and expand beyond search and software....

headline.seo: Motorola to Cut 20% of Work Force, Part of Sweeping Change
headline.main: Motorola Set for Big Cuts as Google Reinvents It
headline.print_headline: Motorola Set For Big Cuts As Google Reinvents It

docs.abstract: Motorola Mobility, ailing cellphone maker that Google bought in May, will lay off 20 percent of its work force, or 4,000 people, and close a third of its 94 offices worldwide; cuts are the first step in Google's plan to reinvent Motorola, and to shore up its Android mobile business and expand beyond search and software into the manufacture of hardware.

byline.contributor: Brian X. Chen contributed reporting from New York.

docs.snippet: When Google imagines the future of Web search, it sees a search engine that understands human meaning and not just words, that can have a spoken conversation with computer users and that gives users results not just from the Web but also from thei...
docs.lead_paragraph: When Google imagines the future of Web search, it sees a search engine that understands human meaning and not just words, that can have a spoken conversation with computer users and that gives users results not just from the Web but also from their personal lives.Last week Google showed a few steps it has taken toward making that all-knowing search engine a reality. The new tools, like a voice search that seems to outdo Apple's Siri, make Google more useful. But some, like a feature that incorporates personal Gmail messages in results, could also unnerve those concerned with privacy.

headline.main: Google Searches Get Personal

docs.abstract: Bits blog notes Google introduces new search tools, including one that incorporates personal Gmail messages in results, which could raise privacy concerns. (M)0

docs.snippet: If you believe someone has a great future as an entrepreneur, maybe you should own a piece of it.That is the premise of an unusual effort by a former Google executive to promote start-ups through the creation of a new investment vehicle. Through t...
docs.lead_paragraph: If you believe someone has a great future as an entrepreneur, maybe you should own a piece of it.That is the premise of an unusual effort by a former Google executive to promote start-ups through the creation of a new investment vehicle. Through the company, Upstart , successful older executives will give enough money to college graduates to see them through the earliest stages of their business ideas.

headline.main: One Part Mentor, One Part Investor

docs.abstract: Bits blog notes former Google executive David Girouard has founded Upstart, which gives advice and financing to young tech entrepreneurs. Photo (M)

docs.snippet: Now it can be told: there is a lot of Wikipedia in the press section at the Olympics. For every reporter who can tell you that a waza-ari was clearly just a glorified yuko or that the Hungarian is the one to watch, there are quite a few more -- th...
docs.lead_paragraph: Now it can be told: there is a lot of Wikipedia in the press section at the Olympics. For every reporter who can tell you that a waza-ari was clearly just a glorified yuko or that the Hungarian is the one to watch, there are quite a few more -- the feature writers, the curious onlookers who normally cover track and field, the poor souls who were assigned a dozen different sports, me -- typing ''judo + rules'' into Google.An argument can be made that this is excusable. There is just so much going on, so many different events in so many different places, all at the same time. Victory ceremonies are squeezed in between long jumps; a fencer's dream is dashed while three other bouts are going on around her; the javelins sail toward the high jumpers.

headline.main: You Had to be There: The Footnotes Tell a Global Story

docs.abstract: Thrilling triumphs and profound disappointments abound at the London Games, but the real spirit of the Olympics also can be found in the small details. Photo (M)

headline.main: Google Says It Will Buy Frommer's For Content

docs.abstract: Google is buying the Frommer's brand of travel guides from John Wiley & Sons for $23 million to expand its local and travel search results. Photo (M)1

docs.snippet: 8:56 p.m. | Updated SAN FRANCISCO -  Google  made another foray into producing original content Monday when it announced its plans to buy the Frommer's brand of travel guides from  John Wiley & Sons  to augment its local and travel search results....
docs.lead_paragraph: 8:56 p.m. | Updated SAN FRANCISCO - Google made another foray into producing original content Monday when it announced its plans to buy the Frommer's brand of travel guides from John Wiley & Sons to augment its local and travel search results.Google will pay about $23 million for the brand, according to a person close to the deal who was not authorized to speak publicly about the terms. The companies declined to comment on the purchase price. It is a small acquisition for Google, but important for several of Google's up-and-coming businesses.

headline.main: Google Says It Will Buy Frommer's For Content

It is expected to increase to $150 billion over all in 2016, not to $150 billion just on the Internet.

docs.snippet: INSIDER TRADING CONVICTION A former California-based hedge fund manager who took the stand in his own defense was convicted of insider trading on Monday.After less than a day of deliberations, a federal jury found Doug Whitman, left, of Whitman Ca...
docs.lead_paragraph: INSIDER TRADING CONVICTION A former California-based hedge fund manager who took the stand in his own defense was convicted of insider trading on Monday.After less than a day of deliberations, a federal jury found Doug Whitman, left, of Whitman Capital in Menlo Park, Calif., guilty of earning about $1 million in illegal profits trading technology stocks, including Google and Polycom. His sentencing is set for Dec. 20. PETER LATTMAN

docs.abstract: Google's efforts to recruit and promote more women have resulted in more hires, but not in the executive offices; since Larry Page became chief executive and reorganized the company in 2011, women have been pushed out of his inner circle and passed over for promotions; Susan Wojcicki, who oversees advertising, is the only woman on Page's committee of close advisers.

docs.snippet: The personal computer market is being squeezed by tablets and powerful smartphones. H.P. said that its PC business was down 10 percent in the fiscal third quarter, and Intel has lowered its projection for the year based on poor retail demand for P...
docs.lead_paragraph: The personal computer market is being squeezed by tablets and powerful smartphones. H.P. said that its PC business was down 10 percent in the fiscal third quarter, and Intel has lowered its projection for the year based on poor retail demand for PCs in the first two quarters. As if iPads weren't enough competition, Google began shipping the Nexus 7 last month, and Microsoft will release its tablet, Surface, in the fall. Laptops themselves are a replacement for desktops and aren't likely to disappear, especially when workers and their families so readily take them on the road. SHELLY FREIERMAN

docs.snippet: The wrench icon in the Google Chrome toolbar offers a menu of settings for controlling and adjusting how the browser looks and behaves. Chrome can also reveal more information on its internal pages with a series of commands typed directly into the...
docs.lead_paragraph: The wrench icon in the Google Chrome toolbar offers a menu of settings for controlling and adjusting how the browser looks and behaves. Chrome can also reveal more information on its internal pages with a series of commands typed directly into the address/search box, also known as the omnibox. While many of these commands are primarily for the use of programmers looking to debug Web page code, some are helpful for quickly seeing what plug-ins and extensions are installed, or to see the browser's bookmarks list. To see a list of available typed commands, click into the Chrome omnibox and type ''chrome:about'' (without the quotation marks or any spaces). In the list, you can click the various links to see all kinds of information about Chrome, including the downloads list, the browser history and cache, the program's memory usage and more. These links can also be typed directly into the Chrome omnibox at any time. The ''chrome:flags'' command even displays a list of hidden experimental features, but the browser warns that you use these at your own risk since they are unofficial.
